data.title: The 65+ Best Movies With Gun in the Title
data.meta_description: Over 100 filmgoers have voted on the 65+ Best Movies With Gun in the Title. Current Top 3: The Shakiest Gun in the West, Young Guns, Top Gun
data.text:
Ranked By

417 votes

137 voters

Voting Rules

Vote up your favorite movie with gun in the name.

Have you ever noticed how many movies there are with gun in the name? This list ranks the best movies with gun in the title, regardless of genre or rating. What is your favorite movie with gun in the name? If you're a James Bond fan then you probably think of The Man With the Golden Gun, a 1974 classic starring Roger Moore as Bond. This is kind of an odd way to categorize movies, but that's also why it's so fun! There are probably one or two movies with gun in the title that you instantly think of, but you might be surprised how many others there are too as you scroll through this list.

This ranked poll of films with gun in the title includes movies like Top Gun, Gun Crazy, and The Naked Gun 2Â½: The Smell of Fear. Don't forget that this list is interactive, meaning you can vote the film names up or down depending on much you liked each movie that has the word gun in it.

Most divisive: 2 Guns

Over 100 Ranker voters have come together to rank this list of The 65+ Best Movies With Gun in the Title

Released : 1968

Directed by : Alan Rafkin

A classic comedic western starring Don Knotts as Jesse W. Haywood, a Philadelphia dentist who inadvertently becomes a skilled marksman while traveling to the Wild West. This hilarious tale is filled with slapstick humor, unexpected plot twists, and a standout performance by Knotts as the bumbling, lovable hero. Its unique blend of comedy and Western action has made it a timeless favorite among gun-centric films.

Emilio Estevez, Kiefer Sutherland, Lou Diamond Phillips

Released : 1988

Directed by : Christopher Cain

This iconic Western film, featuring an ensemble cast of rising stars such as Emilio Estevez, Kiefer Sutherland, and Lou Diamond Phillips, tells the story of a group of young outlaws who become known as the infamous Regulators. Inspired by true events, the movie brings to life the wild adventures and exploits of these young gunslingers as they fight for survival and attempt to clear their names. The movie's mix of thrilling action, engaging storytelling, and a memorable rock-influenced soundtrack has solidified its status as one of the best gun-themed movies of all time.

Tom Cruise, Kelly McGillis, Anthony Edwards

Released : 1986

Directed by : Tony Scott

Starring Tom Cruise as Pete "Maverick" Mitchell, this high-flying drama centers around elite Navy pilots competing to be the best in their class at the prestigious Top Gun Naval Flying School. With thrilling aerial combat sequences, stunning visuals, and a chart-topping soundtrack, it quickly became an iconic film of the 1980s. Its enduring popularity and influence on pop culture make it a must-watch for fans of gun-themed cinema.

Released : 1974

Directed by : Guy Hamilton

As the ninth installment in the legendary James Bond franchise, this film pits 007 against the enigmatic assassin Francisco Scaramanga, played by Christopher Lee, who uses a unique golden gun as his weapon of choice. Featuring exotic locales, thrilling action sequences, and the ever-charming Roger Moore as James Bond, this entry into the series is a memorable and exciting classic. The titular golden gun remains one of the most iconic weapons in film history.

Released : 1961

Directed by : J. Lee Thompson

Based on the best-selling novel by Alistair MacLean, this World War II epic follows a group of Allied commandos on a daring mission to destroy massive German guns on the Aegean island of Navarone. Featuring an all-star cast led by Gregory Peck, David Niven, and Anthony Quinn, the film boasts stunning visuals, gripping action sequences, and a powerful story of heroism and sacrifice. Its status as one of the greatest war films ever made cements its place among the finest movies featuring guns.

Released : 1991

Directed by : David Zucker

The second installment in the hilarious Naked Gun series finds bumbling Lt. Frank Drebin attempting to save the day once again, this time from an eco-terrorist plot involving an energy crisis. With its signature blend of slapstick humor, outrageous gags, and nonstop wordplay, the film is a worthy follow-up to the original spoof comedy. Its irreverent approach to the genre, gun-focused comedy, and memorable performances contribute to its status as one of the best gun-centric movies ever made.
